STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: Now I'll select treatments based on current clinical guidelines. - First-line treatment per guidelines: Mood stabilizers such as lamotrigine or lithium, with adjunctive psychotherapy. - Supporting evidence: Lamotrigine is effective for bipolar depression and prevents mood episodes; lithium has mood-stabilizing and anti-suicidal properties. - Patient-specific considerations: Best suited for bipolar II disorder with depressive predominance; history of cognitive barriers suggests simplified medication regimens may enhance adherence. - Contraindications or cautions: Monitor for skin rash with lamotrigine; lithium requires renal and thyroid function monitoring.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: If medications are appropriate, I'll select based on efficacy and safety. - Primary medication choice: Lamotrigine, starting at 25 mg daily, titrated gradually to 100-200 mg daily as tolerated. - Rationale for selection: Effective in bipolar depression, well tolerated, and has a favorable side effect profile. - Expected timeline for improvement: Some mood stabilization may occur within 4-6 weeks; full effect may take longer. - Key side effects to monitor: Rash (discontinue if Stevens-Johnson syndrome suspected), headache, gastrointestinal upset. - Alternative medications if first-line fails: Lithium, valproate, or antipsychotics like quetiapine (if agitation or mixed features develop).  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: I'll include lifestyle and behavioral interventions that enhance outcomes. - Primary non-drug interventions: Psychoeducation on mood stability, sleep hygiene, routine establishment. - Patient education priorities: Recognize early warning signs, medication adherence importance, avoid substance use. - Lifestyle modifications: Consistent sleep schedule, balanced diet, regular physical activity, stress reduction techniques. - Behavioral interventions: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), possibly supplemented with psychoeducational groups.  STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: I'll establish appropriate monitoring and follow-up care. - Follow-up timeline: Reassess in 2 weeks after medication initiation, then every 4-6 weeks until stabilization. - Monitoring parameters: Mood symptoms, medication side effects, adherence, sleep patterns, suicidal ideation. - Red flag symptoms: Increasing suicidal thoughts, rapid mood swings, emergence of psychosis, severe side effects. - Treatment response assessment: Improvement in mood stability, decreased mood fluctuations, adherence. STEP 7 - COORDINATION & REFERRALS: What additional care coordination is needed? - Specialist referrals needed: Psychiatry consultation for medication management; consider mood disorder specialist if available. - Other healthcare team members: Mental health therapists for psychotherapy; possibly a case manager for adherence support. - Community resources: Bipolar support groups, psychoeducation workshops. - Insurance/cost considerations: Discuss medication costs, available assistance programs, and coverage for psychotherapy.
